## Table of contents

## Stellar spectra and black bodies

Stars don't have a definite surface &mdash; the light we see from a star comes from a layer of gas several hundreds of km thick, known as the **photosphere**.

When light is emitted by a hot object like a star, we expect the light to have a wide range of wavelengths similar to the spectrum of a black body.

<Callout emoji="⚡️">

A black body is a body (or surface) which absorbs all the electromagnetic radiation that falls upon it. Nothing is a better emitter of radiation at any wavelengths than a black body at the same temperature.

</Callout>

### The spectrum observed from a star

Stars emit light as a continuous spectrum of radiation. This comes from the dense gas of the surface of the star.

<div className="flex justify-center mt-6">

However, this light must pass through the gases in the star&apos;s <Tooltip.Provider><Tooltip.Root><Tooltip.Trigger asChild><Button variant="link" size={null}>tenuous</Button></Tooltip.Trigger><Tooltip.Content>The star's atmopshere is a lot thinner (less dense) than the gases forming the surface.</Tooltip.Content></Tooltip.Root></Tooltip.Provider> atmosphere.

This is called a **line absorption spectrum**, as shown in the image below.

### Black body spectrum

The intensity of the radiation emitted from a black body varies with the wavelength.

The curves below show how the intensity of the radiation varies with wavelength for black bodies at different temperatures.

The shape of the curve (the black body spectrum) is similar for each temperature.

However, notice that:

- the higher the temperature, the higher the peak intensity
- the higher the temperature, the lower is the peak intensity wavelength, i.e. the peak is shifted to the left at higher temperatures
- the lower the temperature, the longer the &apos;flat&apos; section is before the curve &apos;lifts off&apos;.

## Wein's law

When the intensity of each small section of this is studied carefully, it is found to follow Wien&apos;s law:

<Callout emoji="⚡️">

The wavelength of peak emission from a black body is inversely proportional to the absolute (kelvin) temperature of the body:

$$
\lambda _{\text{max}} = \frac{W}{t}
$$

</Callout>

<Columns left="where,">

$\lambda _\text{max}$ = the peak wavelength, m;

$W$ = Wein's constant = $2.90 \times 10^{-3}$ mK; and

$T$ = the surface temperature of a star (K)

</Columns>

#### Absolute temperature, $T$

The absolute temperature, $T$, in kelvin (K) is related to the temperature, $\theta$, in degrees Celcius (&deg;C) by:

$$
\frac{T}{\text{K}} = \frac{\theta}{\text{°C}} + 273.15
$$

At 0 K, (-273.15&deg;C), the energy of particles in a body is the lowest it can possibly be.

## The inverse square law of light and Stefan&apos;s law

As you go further from a light source the amount of light energy striking each square metre each second decreases. This is because the light initially emitted is spread out over a larger and larger &apos;surface area&apos; as it travels away from the source.

The &apos;amount of light energy striking each metre square per second&apos; is known as the spectral intensity, $I$, sometimes known as &apos;flux density&apos; or &apos;flux&apos;.

$$
I = \frac{P}{4\pi R^2}
$$

<Columns left="where,">

$I$ = intensity of the radiation, Wm<sup>-2</sup>;

$P$ = total power (luminosity) produced by the star, W; and

$R$ = distance from the star

</Columns>

Note that $4 \pi R^2$ is the surface area of an &apos;imaginary&apos; sphere of radius, $R$.

### Stefan&apos; law

It is found that the intensity of the light (the power per metre square), **at the surface of a star**, is directly proportional to the fourth power of the surface temperature. This is known as **Stefan&apos;s law**:

<Callout emoji="⚡️">

The total electromagnetic radiation energy emitted per unit time by a black body is given by:

$$
P = A \sigma T^4
$$

</Callout>

Dividing both sides by the area, $A$, the left side bcomes $\frac{P}{A}$ and in the intensity again ($I=\frac{P}{A}$), except this time:

$A$ = surface area of the star = $4\pi R^2$, where $R$ = radius of star;

$\sigma$ = Stefan&apos;s constant = $5.67 \times 10^{-8}$ Wm<sup>-2</sup>K<sup>-4</sup>; and

$T$ = absolute surface temperature of the star (K)

### Luminosity of a star

The **luminosity** of a star is the total energy it emits per unit time in the form of electromagnetic radiation.

The unit of luminosity is the watt, W.

Therefore, luminosity is equivalent to the power of the star.

This means we could have written luminosity instead of power in Stefan&apos;s law.

## Multiwavelength astronomy

Studying stars and space by making observations outside of the visible light spectrum can give more information about the processes which took place.

For example, observing using the **microwave** region of the spectrum revealed the cosmic microwave background radiation (CMBR).

A galaxy can be studied using different telescopes which are sensitive to different wavelengths of the electromagnetic spectrum. This is called **multiwavelength astronomy**.

With the exception of visible light astronomy, the colours are &apos;false colours&apos;, i.e. the colour is an intensity code rather than an actual colour.

The image below shows the **visible light** from a galaxy. This was taken using an optical telescope.
